title: Brit dad has cancer so rare 'he's only found two other people in UK with it'
text:

A British dad battling a rare cancer is desperate to get treatment from the only medical team in the world who have successfully helped a patient beat the illness.

DJ Chad Alexander, from Basingstoke, has been diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of kidney cancer called Renal Medullary Carcinoma (RMC).

The 30-year-old father-of-two young children has been dismayed to learn the treatment he desperately needs for the cancer is not funded by the NHS - and is so far only available in the United States.

The DJ and educator, originally from Chelsea, is reportedly only the second person in the UK to have been diagnosed with the sickle cell trait that causes the disease.

Chad, who has a partner and children aged four and one, told Metro he has had to quit working while he fights the cancer following major surgery to remove a tumour in his kidney.

(Image: chadalexanderuk/Instagram)

(Image: chadalexanderuk/Instagram)

He said: "Emotionally, just knowing you have cancer by itself is bad, but figuring out it is this type of rare cancer is terrible."



Chad has begun crowd-funding for help to get him to the US, where doctors in Houston, Texas, have previously successfully treated a patient with the same illness.

His goal is to raise £50,000 to travel to seek treatment from the medical team at the MD Anderson Cancer Center.

More than 1,000 have already raised more than £34,000 for the DJ via his JustGiving page where he shared the details of his illness in an effort to raise awareness about the signs of the rare cancer.

In his crowdfunding post, Chad says the first sign something was wrong came when blood suddenly began appearing in his urine in late June.

A month later he got a CT scan, which revealed a "large tumour" in his kidney.

(Image: chadalexanderuk/Instagram)

On September 19 he underwent a six-hour operation which saw surgeons remove the tumour, as well as his left kidney, his spleen, the tail of his pancreas, and a small part of his diaphragm.

He finally received the devastating diagnosis of RMC on Friday.

Chad wrote: "The research I have done so far has been disheartening, not only is it difficult to even find people who have had this type of cancer but finding people who are still alive is even harder still.

"Often this cancer is diagnosed late which further decreases survival chances, so even though my surgery at the moment appears successful we know there is still at least one tumour on my lung. HOWEVER there is hope!"

Chad wrote that he had found an American survivor of RMC who had been treated at the Houston clinic.

(Image: chadalexanderuk/Instagram)

He made swift contact with the clinic and claims they told him an initial appointment alone would cost US $25,000 (about £20,000) before treatment, flights and accommodation.

He said he and his partner, a nurse, live in Basingstoke with their children.

They were asking the public and the DJ's fans for help coming up with the funds, which has forced them onto a single income as Chad has been left unable to work due to his illness.

He wrote: "Any money you are able to donate will be so greatly appreciated but also please spread the word.

"If you know anyone who is a sickle cell trait carrier or has sickle cell disease please make them aware of Renal Medullary Carcinoma. My symptoms included blood in the urine, back/ flank pain and weight loss."

According to the National Organisation for Rare Diseases, RMC is one of the most aggressive forms of kidney cancers, and predominantly affects young men of African descent who carry the sickle cell trait for the disease.

According to WebMD , while renal cell carcinoma-type cancers like RMC can be treated, radiation and chemotherapy have limited effectiveness.

Scientists are currently exploring new and better treatments and working on drug trials in hopes of fighting the disease.

You can donate to Chad's fundraising page here .
description: DJ Chad Alexander, 30, is desperate to access cutting-edge treatment in the USA for Renal Medullary Carcinoma
